pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 304, 209]]<|/det|>
# FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 217, 154, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF10)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 320, 390, 338]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 367, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 384, 327, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 500, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 447, 285, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 462, 907, 493]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 493, 507, 509]]<|/det|>
The use of a calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 509, 907, 540]]<|/det|>
Results obtained solely from a graphic calculator, without supporting working or reasoning, will not receive credit.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 606, 556]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 570, 606, 585]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 586, 756, 602]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 722, 92]]<|/det|>
The equation \(x^{3} + px + q = 0\) has a repeated root. Prove that \(4p^{3} + 27q^{2} = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 120, 96, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 762, 139]]<|/det|>
The position vectors of points \(A, B, C\), relative to the origin \(O\), are \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}, \mathbf{c}\), where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 146, 720, 165]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{a} = 3\mathbf{i} + 2\mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k},\qquad \mathbf{b} = 4\mathbf{i} - 3\mathbf{j} + 2\mathbf{k},\qquad \mathbf{c} = 3\mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 172, 534, 191]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}\) and deduce the area of the triangle \(OAB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 173, 920, 191]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 202, 920, 238]]<|/det|>
Hence find the volume of the tetrahedron \(OABC\), given that the volume of a tetrahedron is \(\frac{1}{3} \times\) area of base \(\times\) perpendicular height.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 220, 920, 238]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 266, 96, 285]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 266, 631, 285]]<|/det|>
Prove by mathematical induction that, for all positive integers \(n\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 291, 636, 322]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}^{n}}{\mathrm{dx}^{n}} (\mathrm{e}^{x} \sin x) = 2^{\frac{1}{n}} \mathrm{e}^{x} \sin (x + \frac{1}{4} n \pi).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 297, 920, 316]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 363, 96, 381]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 361, 732, 381]]<|/det|>
The linear transformation \(\mathrm{T}: \mathbb{R}^{4} \to \mathbb{R}^{4}\) is represented by the matrix \(\mathbf{M}\), where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 386, 615, 457]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{M} = \left( \begin{array}{cccc}3 & 4 & 2 & 5 \\ 6 & 7 & 5 & 8 \\ 9 & 9 & 9 & 9 \\ 15 & 16 & 14 & 17 \end{array} \right).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 463, 160, 481]]<|/det|>
<label>Find</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 488, 561, 507]]<|/det|>
(i) the rank of \(\mathbf{M}\) and a basis for the range space of T,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 488, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 513, 151, 531]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 513, 400, 531]]<|/det|>
a basis for the null space of T.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 513, 920, 532]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 559, 96, 578]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 559, 515, 578]]<|/det|>
The point \(P\) (2, 1) lies on the curve with equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 584, 561, 604]]<|/det|>
\[x^{3} - 2y^{3} = 3xy.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 612, 158, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>Find</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 635, 153, 655]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 635, 326, 660]]<|/det|>
the value of \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\) at \(P\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 640, 920, 658]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 675, 151, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 675, 332, 702]]<|/det|>
the value of \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{dx}^{2}}\) at \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 680, 920, 698]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 740, 96, 761]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 733, 576, 771]]<|/det|>
Let \(I_{n} = \int_{0}^{1} x^{n} (1 - x)^{\frac{1}{2}} \mathrm{~d} x\), for \(n \geqslant 0\). Show that, for \(n \geqslant 1\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 778, 579, 797]]<|/det|>
\[(3 + 2n)I_n = 2nI_{n - 1}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 778, 920, 797]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 819, 376, 836]]<|/det|>
Hence find the exact value of \(I_{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 819, 920, 836]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 97, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{x^{2} + px + 1}{x - 2}\) , where \(p\) is a constant. Given that \(C\) has two asymptotes, find the equation of each asymptote. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 131, 680, 151]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(p\) for which \(C\) has two distinct turning points. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\) in the case \(p = - 1\). Your sketch should indicate the coordinates of any intersections with the axes, but need not show the coordinates of any turning points. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 225, 96, 243]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 223, 920, 274]]<|/det|>
The vector \(\mathbf{e}\) is an eigenvector of the matrix \(\mathbf{A}\), with corresponding eigenvalue \(\lambda\), and is also an eigenvector of the matrix \(\mathbf{B}\), with corresponding eigenvalue \(\mu\). Show that \(\mathbf{e}\) is an eigenvector of the matrix \(\mathbf{AB}\) with corresponding eigenvalue \(\lambda \mu\). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 286, 475, 305]]<|/det|>
State the eigenvalues of the matrix \(\mathbf{C}\), where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 310, 593, 364]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{C} = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} - 1 & - 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 0 & 2 \end{array} \right),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 369, 415, 388]]<|/det|>
and find corresponding eigenvectors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 370, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 399, 560, 445]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 6 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}\) is an eigenvector of the matrix \(\mathbf{D}\), where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 445, 593, 500]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{D} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & -1 & 1 \\ -6 & -3 & 4 \\ -9 & -3 & 7 \end{pmatrix},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 503, 435, 521]]<|/det|>
and state the corresponding eigenvalue.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 503, 920, 521]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 533, 789, 552]]<|/det|>
Hence state an eigenvector of the matrix \(\mathbf{CD}\) and give the corresponding eigenvalue. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 580, 96, 599]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 580, 620, 599]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{1}{2} (\mathrm{e}^{x} + \mathrm{e}^{- x})\) for \(0\leqslant x\leqslant \ln 5\) . Find

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 606, 688, 625]]<|/det|>
(i) the mean value of \(y\) with respect to \(x\) over the interval \(0\leqslant x\leqslant \ln 5\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 631, 151, 650]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 631, 316, 650]]<|/det|>
the arc length of \(C\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 631, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 655, 156, 673]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 655, 806, 673]]<|/det|>
the surface area generated when \(C\) is rotated through \(2\pi\) radians about the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 655, 920, 673]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 702, 104, 720]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 702, 920, 736]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r = 3 + 2\cos \theta\), for \(-\pi < \theta \leqslant \pi\). The straight line \(l\) has polar equation \(r\cos \theta = 2\). Sketch both \(C\) and \(l\) on a single diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 720, 920, 739]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 747, 643, 766]]<|/det|>
Find the polar coordinates of the points of intersection of \(C\) and \(l\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 747, 920, 766]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 778, 744, 797]]<|/det|>
The region \(R\) is enclosed by \(C\) and \(l\), and contains the pole. Find the area of \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 778, 920, 797]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[323, 852, 675, 871]]<|/det|>
**[Question 11 is printed on the next page.]**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 526, 92]]<|/det|>
Answer only **one** of the following two alternatives.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 201, 123]]<|/det|>
# EITHER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 625, 154]]<|/det|>
Let \(\omega = \cos \frac{1}{5}\pi + \mathrm{i}\sin \frac{1}{5}\pi\). Show that \(\omega^{5} + 1 = 0\) and deduce that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 163, 594, 182]]<|/det|>
\[\omega^{4} - \omega^{3} + \omega^{2} - \omega = -1.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 165, 918, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 205, 262, 223]]<|/det|>
Show further that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 225, 680, 245]]<|/det|>
\[\omega -\omega^{4} = 2\cos {\frac{1}{5}}\pi \quad \mathrm{and}\quad \omega^{3} - \omega^{2} = 2\cos {\frac{3}{5}}\pi .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 227, 918, 246]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 265, 316, 284]]<|/det|>
Hence find the values of

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 289, 650, 312]]<|/det|>
\[\cos {\frac{1}{5}}\pi +\cos {\frac{3}{5}}\pi \quad \mathrm{and}\quad \cos {\frac{1}{5}}\pi \cos {\frac{3}{5}}\pi .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 335, 873, 355]]<|/det|>
Find a quadratic equation having roots \(\cos \frac{1}{5}\pi\) and \(\cos \frac{3}{5}\pi\) and deduce the exact value of \(\cos \frac{1}{5}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 337, 918, 356]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 368, 153, 386]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 400, 207, 417]]<|/det|>
Given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 418, 682, 450]]<|/det|>
\[x^{2}\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{d}x^{2}} +4x(1 + x)\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} +2(1 + 4x + 2x^{2})y = 8x^{2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 456, 336, 475]]<|/det|>
and that \(x^{2}y = z\), show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 477, 591, 510]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}z}{\mathrm{d}x^{2}} +4\frac{\mathrm{d}z}{\mathrm{d}x} +4z = 8x^{2}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 484, 918, 504]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 529, 472, 549]]<|/det|>
Find the general solution for \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 530, 918, 549]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 561, 430, 579]]<|/det|>
Describe the behaviour of \(y\) as \(x \to \infty\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 561, 920, 579]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]
